Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Supramolecular anion-pi and halogen-bonded complexes and their role in electron-transfer processes
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program in the Division of Chemistry, Professor Sergiy Rosokha of the Department of Chemistry at Ball State University studies intermolecular interactions between molecules that have a halogen atom (fluorine, chlorine, bromine, iodine) and molecules with a negative charge (anions). These types of chemical interactions are recognized as a powerful tool for recognizing molecules, preparing materials, and designing pharmaceuticals. Professor Rosokha is studying the role of these novel types of intermolecular interactions in facilitating certain chemical reactions. These mechanistic studies should aid the development of more efficient synthetic methods and the study of chemical reactions in the environment. Professor Rosokha is also providing research and training opportunities for undergraduate and masters students at Ball State University.

Professor Rosokha is studying the mechanistic role of anion-pi and halogen-bonded complexes in electron-transfer reactions. More generally, he is addressing solution-phase chemical transformations of both halogenated electrophiles and anionic nucleophiles. Through a combination of spectral (UV-Vis, FT-IR, NMR, ESR) measurements, electrochemical, X-ray structural studies, and computational analysis, Professor Rosokha is establishing the structural, thermodynamic and spectral characteristics of highly-reactive pre-equilibrium halogen-bonded and anion-pi complexes. The properties of these complexes are then being used to explain, predict and, ultimately, control kinetics and stereochemistry of the reactions of halogen-containing molecules with anions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Anion-π and halogen bondings are counter-intuitive attractions between  negatively charged species or halogen substituents in one molecule to another chemical species. Anions and halogens are abundant in chemical systems and in environment, and numerous examples of anion-p and halogen-bonded associations were identified in the solid-state and in solutions, as well as in the biochemical systems during the last two decades. Scientists realized that these interaction can be fruitfully utilized for preparation of useful materials (such as molecular conductors), rational design of pharmaceutical substances and many other applications. Preliminary data also pointed out that these interactions might affect reactions of anionic and/or halogenated species. With the support from the National Science Foundation we elucidated how anion-π and halogen bonding affect transfer of smallest chemical particle, an electron, between interacting species. Electron transfer is one of the simplest and most common chemical reactions, and it frequently represents a first step in complicated chemical transformations. As such, studies of this process provide insight into mechanism of chemical reactions and are critical for the development of more efficient synthetic methods and for the understanding chemical processes in the living beings and in environment.

We demonstrated that anion-π interaction and halogen bonding considerably increase rates of electron transfer between interacting species. It allowed to explain why many such reactions were much faster than predicted by classic electron-transfer theory and to account for involvement of electron-transfer step in many chemical transformations. We found that an increase in electron-transfer rates is related to the electronic coupling between anion-π or halogen-bonded species akin to that occurring between atoms in conventional intramolecular (covalent) bonds. This means that besides electrostatic attraction, which is most commonly considered as a main driving force of attraction between different ions and molecules, anion-π interaction and halogen bonding involve weakly covalent component. The latter provides a channel facilitating movement of electrons, and its involvement leads to appearance of new absorption bands in the spectra of complexes. Accordingly, the rates of electron transfer in such systems can be predicted via analysis of the spectral characteristics of complexes. This makes it possible to clarify mechanism of many chemical reactions of anionic or halogenated species and  to design new chemical processes. Also, this weakly?covalent component helps to overcome electrostatic repulsion and bring together similarly-charged species. This significantly extend areas of potential applications of these intermolecular interactions. We also showed that the gradual increase of the contribution of the weakly-covalent component in a series of halogen-bonded complexes leads to transformation of the intermolecular bond into covalent (intramolecular) chemical bond. Such continuum transition revealed intrinsic link between the limiting types of bonding, which further advance the development of the fundamental concept of chemical bond.         

This grant also had a broader impact. It resulted in improvement of facilities and general research environment at the Department of Chemistry at Ball State University. Financial support from the NSF enabled to engage seventeen undergraduate and three graduate students (including underrepresented in science minorities) in the state-of-the art scientific project. It helped to improve students? experimental skills and basic knowledge of chemistry, as well as data treatment and analysis. Collaborative research, presentations at scientific meetings, from the group?s seminars and Ball State Students Symposia to International and National Conferences, preparation of reports and manuscript (twelve students became co-authors of the articles published in the high-level scientific journals) enhanced students? teamwork, leadership, and communication skills. Participation in the project encouraged undergraduate students to continue education in the graduate programs in Chemistry or Chemical Engineering, and in medical schools. 

Since anion-π and halogen bonding are novel and largely unknown concept even for chemical community, PI made presen?ta?tions at a number of scientific conferences as well as at five presentations at Chemistry seminars at various Universities which improved awareness about the nature, properties and applications of this long overlooked interaction.
